docs.snippet: No. 2 candidates always use their debates to promote and defend the top of the ticket, but Mr. Pence’s role came after a week of outbursts from Donald Trump....
docs.lead_paragraph: No. 2 candidates always use their debates to promote and defend the top of the ticket, but Mr. Pence’s role came after a week of outbursts from Donald Trump.
docs.abstract: Sen Tim Kaine and Gov Mike Pence clash during vice presidential debate, trading attacks and defenses of their running mates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump; Kaine appears far more aggressive than Pence, who assumes moderate tone that provided counterpoint to Trump's bombast in first presidential debate week before.

headline.main: Tim Kaine and Mike Pence Clash Sharply Over Their Running Mates
headline.print_headline: Kaine and Pence  Clash on Merits of Their Tickets

byline.contributor: Jonathan Martin reported from Farmville, and Patrick Healy from New York.
byline.original: By JONATHAN MARTIN and PATRICK HEALY

docs.snippet: On his organization’s 10th anniversary, he vowed to release “significant material” about a range of issues, including the U.S. election....

docs.abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange plans to release 'significant material' on several subjects, including United States election, over 10 weeks; refutes idea that election-related material, set for release before Nov 8, is meant to harm Hillary Clinton and vows to continue providing platform for classified document leaks.

headline.main: Julian Assange, WikiLeaks Founder, Promises Raft of Revelations
headline.print_headline: Assange Sets New Schedule of Disclosures

docs.snippet: An estimated 37 million Americans watched the U.S. vice presidential debate between Republican Mike Pence and Democrat Tim Kaine on television, according to Nielsen data on Wednesday, less than half the number who tuned in to Donald Trump's first ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 37 million Americans watched the U.S. vice presidential debate between Republican Mike Pence and Democrat Tim Kaine on television, according to Nielsen data on Wednesday, less than half the number who tuned in to Donald Trump's first matchup with Hillary Clinton last week.

headline.main: U.S. Vice Presidential Debate Watched by 37 Million on TV
